hints_html:
Recall that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}M^{-1}M=I.\end{aligned}\]

How can this help us simplify \(\displaystyle {}A^k\)?
hints_raw:
Recall that

:<math>
\displaystyle{}M^{-1}M=I.
</math>

How can this help us simplify <math>\displaystyle{}A^k</math>?
question: 4 (d)
sols_html:
From part (c), we have that \(\displaystyle A = MDM^{-1}\) where

\[\begin{aligned} M = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} M^{-1}=\begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & -1/2\\ 1/2 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} D = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 5 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Taking powers yields

\[\begin{aligned} A^{k} &= (MDM^{-1})^k \\ &= MDM^{-1} \cdot MDM^{-1}\cdot \ldots \cdot MDM^{-1} \\ &= MD^{k}M^{-1} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 5^{k} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & -1/2 \\ 1/2 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\begin{bmatrix} 1 +5^{k} & -1 + 5^{k} \\ -1 +5^{k} & 1 + 5^{k} \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Consider the matrix

\[\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2\\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Use part (c) to explicitly compute \(A^k\) for any positive integer k.
